LOTlib.Hypotheses.DecayedLikelihoodHypothesis module¶

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.DecayedLikelihoodHypothesis.DecayedLikelihoodHypothesis(value=None, ll_decay=0.0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis.Hypothesis

This implements a likelihood decay such that more recent data is weighted more strongly, via the parameter ll_decay

By default, we store the likelihoods for each data point (as we may fit ll_decay)

TODO: MAKE THIS WORK AGAIN! THIS HAS BEEN UPDATED AFTER EXTRACTING FROM HYPOTHESIS CLASS

compute_likelihood(data)[source]¶

This is overwritten, writes to stored_likelihood, and then calls get_culmulative_likelihoods

get_culmulative_likelihoods(shift_right=True)[source]¶

Compute the culmulative likelihoods on the stored data This gives the likelihood on the first data point, the first two, first three, etc, appropriately decayed using the ‘pointwise’ likelihoods stored in self.stored_likelihood. NOTE: This is O(N^2) (for power law decays; for geometric it could be linear) returns: a numpy array of the likelihoods

  • shift_right – do we insert a “0” at the beginning (corresponding to inferences with 0 data), and then delete one from the end?
    • So if you do posterior predictives, you want shift_right=True
get_culmulative_posteriors(shift_right=False)[source]¶

returns the posterior with the i’th stored CULMULATIVE likelihood, using the assumed decay

likelihood_decay_function(i, N, decay)[source]¶

The weight of the likelihood for the ith point out of N with the given decay parameter. Generally, this should be a power law decay i - What data point (0-indexed) N - how many total data points

LOTlib.Hypotheses.FunctionHypothesis module¶

A special type of hypothesis whose value is a function. The function is automatically eval-ed when we set_value, and is automatically hidden and unhidden when we pickle This can also be called like a function, as in fh(data)!

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.FunctionHypothesis.FunctionHypothesis(value=None, f=None, args=['x'], **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis.Hypothesis

A special type of hypothesis whose value is a function. The function is automatically eval-ed when we set_value, and is automatically hidden and unhidden when we pickle This can also be called like a function, as in fh(data)!

__call__(*vals)[source]¶

Make this callable just like a function (as in: myFunction(data)). Yay python!

__copy__()[source]¶

Create a copy, only deeply of f value

__getstate__()[source]¶

We copy the current dict so that when we pickle, we destroy the function

__setstate__(state)[source]¶

sets the state of the hypothesis (when we unpickle)

__str__()[source]¶

Strings of FunctionHypotheses wrap in an implicit lambda and args

compile_function()[source]¶

Takes my value and returns what function I compute. Internally cached by set_value

NOTE: This must be overwritten by subclasses to something useful–see LOTHypothesis

compute_single_likelihood(datum)[source]¶

A function that must be implemented by subclasses to compute the likelihood of a single datum/response pair. This should NOT implement the temperature (that is handled by compute_likelihood)

force_function(f)[source]¶

Sets the function to f, ignoring value. :param f: - a python function (object) :return:

reset_function()[source]¶

re-construct the function from the value – useful after pickling

set_value(value, f=None)[source]¶

Sets the value for the hypothesis. Another option: send f if speed is necessary

LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis module¶

Hypothesis – superclass for hypotheses in Bayesian inference.

A Hypothesis mainly supports .compute_prior() and .compute_likelihood(data), which are called by sampling
and search algorithms.
class LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis.Hypothesis(value=None, prior_temperature=1.0, likelihood_temperature=1.0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A hypothesis bundles together a value (hypothesis value) with a bunch of remembered states, like posterior_score, prior, likelihood.

This class is typically a superclass of the thing you really want.

Note

Temperatures: By default, a Hypothesis has a prior_temperature and likelihood_temperature. These
are taken into account in setting the posterior_score (for computer_prior and compute_likelihood), in the values returned by these, AND in the stored values under self.prior and self.likelihood
Parameters:
  • value – The default value for the hypothesis.
  • prior_temperature – Temperature used when running compute_prior.
  • likelihood_temperature – Temperature used when running compute_likelihood.
__copy__()[source]¶

Returns a copy of the Hypothesis object by calling copy() on self.value.

compute_likelihood(data, **kwargs)[source]¶

Compute the likelihood of the iterable of data.

This is typically NOT subclassed, as compute_single_likelihood is what subclasses should implement.

Versions using decayed likelihood can be found in Hypothesis.DecayedLikelihoodHypothesis.

compute_posterior(d)[source]¶

Computes the posterior score by computing the prior and likelihood scores.

Defaultly if the prior is -inf, we don’t compute the likelihood (and “pretend” it’s -Infinity).

This saves us from computing likelihoods on hypotheses that we know are bad.

compute_prior()[source]¶

Compute the prior and stores it in self.prior.

Note

This method must be implemented when writing subclasses of Hypothesis This should take into account prior_temperature

compute_single_likelihood(datum, **kwargs)[source]¶

Compute the likelihood of a single data point datum, under this hypothesis.

Note

This method must be implemented when writing subclasses of Hypothesis. It should NOT take into account likelihood_temperature, as this is done in compute_likelihood.

enumerative_proposer()[source]¶

Note: This method must be implemented when performing Gibbs sampling

propose()[source]¶

Generic proposal used by MCMC methods.

This should return a list fb, newh, where fb is the forward-minus-backward log probability of the proposal, and newh is the proposal itself (of the same type as self).

Note

This method must be implemented when writing subclasses of Hypothesis

set_value(value)[source]¶

Sets the (self.)value of this hypothesis to value.

update_posterior()[source]¶

So we can save on space when writing this out in every hypothesis.

LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).¶

LOTlib.Hypotheses.LOTHypothesis module¶

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.LOTHypothesis.LOTHypothesis(grammar, value=None, f=None, start=None, ALPHA=0.9, maxnodes=25, args=['x'], proposal_function=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.FunctionHypothesis.FunctionHypothesis

A FunctionHypothesis built from a grammar.

Parameters:
  • grammar (LOTLib.Grammar) – The grammar for the hypothesis.
  • value – The value for the hypothesis.
  • f – If specified, we don’t recompile the whole function.
  • start – The start symbol for the grammar.
  • ALPHA (float) – Parameter for compute_single_likelihood that.
  • maxnodes (int) – The maximum amount of nodes that the grammar can have
  • args (list) – The arguments to the function.
  • proposal_function – Function that tells the program how to transition from one tree to another (by default, it uses the RegenerationProposal function)
__copy__()[source]¶

Make a deepcopy of everything except grammar (which is the, presumably, static grammar).

compile_function()[source]¶

Called in set_value to compile into a function.

compute_prior()[source]¶

Compute the log of the prior probability.

compute_single_likelihood(datum)[source]¶

Computes the likelihood of the data

The data here is from LOTlib.Data and is of the type FunctionData This assumes binary function data – maybe it should be a BernoulliLOTHypothesis

propose(**kwargs)[source]¶

Computes a very similar derivation from the current derivation, using the proposal function we specified as an option when we created an instance of LOTHypothesis

set_proposal_function(f)[source]¶

Just a setter to create the proposal function.

type()[source]¶

LOTlib.Hypotheses.SimpleGenerativeHypothesis module¶

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.SimpleGenerativeHypothesis.SimpleGenerativeHypothesis(grammar, nsamples=100, sm=0.001, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.LOTHypothesis.LOTHypothesis

Here, each data point is a mapping from input to a dict of counts of observed outputs, where if you have K total outputs (sum(output.values()), that counts as K datapoints

Each function eval results in a string, and the likelihood is the probability of generating the observed data. The function eval results in a thunk

NOTE: FOR NOW, Insert/Delete moves are taken off because of some weirdness with the lambda thunks

compute_single_likelihood(datum, llcounts=None)[source]¶

sm smoothing counts are added to existing bins of counts (just to prevent badness) This can take an optiona llcounts in order to allow us to cache this externally

make_ll_counts(*input)[source]¶

Run this model forward nsamples times, returning a dictionary of how often each outcome occurred

By itself this has no likelihood function.

set_word(w, v=None)[source]¶

This sets word w to value v. v can be either None, a FunctionNode or a Hypothesis, and in either case it is copied here. When it is a Hypothesis, the value is extracted. If it is None, we generate from the grammar

LOTlib.Hypotheses.VectorHypothesis module¶

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.VectorHypothesis.VectorHypothesis(value=None, n=1, proposal=None)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.Hypothesis.Hypothesis

Store n-dimensional vectors (defaultly with Gaussian proposals).

conditional_distribution(data, value_index, vals=array([ 0., 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1., 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.8]))[source]¶

Compute posterior values for this grammar, varying specified value over a specified set.

Parameters:
  • data (list) – List of datums.
  • rule_name (string) – Index of the value we’re varying probabilities over.
  • vals (list) – List of float values. E.g. [0,.2,.4, ..., 2.]
Returns:

List of posterior scores, where each item corresponds to an item in vals argument.
Return type:

list
propose()[source]¶

new value is sampled from a normal centered @ old values, w/ proposal as covariance (inverse?)

LOTlib.Hypotheses.WeightedLexicon module¶

class LOTlib.Hypotheses.WeightedLexicon.WeightedLexicon(make_hypothesis, words=(), alpha=0.9, palpha=0.9, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.SimpleLexicon.SimpleLexicon

A weighted lexicon is a lexicon where each word has a weight.

We generate from the presuppositionally-valid utterances with probability palpha, and then when valid, we generate from the true utterances with probability alpha, and then within each set proportional to weightfunction(utterance, context).

__call__(utterance, context)[source]¶

Evaluate this lexicon on a possible utterance, passing the context as an argument

__copy__()[source]¶

Copy a.valueicon. We don’t re-create the fucntions since that’s unnecessary and slow

compute_single_likelihood(udi)[source]¶

Compute the likelihood of a single data point, udi, an utteranceData

partition_utterances(utterances, context)[source]¶

Take some utterances and a context. Returns 3 lists, giving those utterances that are true/false/other in the context

sample_utterance(possible_utterances, context)[source]¶
weightfunction(u, context)[source]¶

The weight of an uterance in a context. Defaults to 1.0 (uniform)
